JOSEPH H. WHITE, M.D., DIRECTOR
August, 4th. 1924.
Dear Dr. Carter,
div1.p:
Your recent letter I have for the moment not at hand,
but I can answer it just as well. I have just finished
reading your article on the “Endemicity of Yellow Fever” and
I quite agree with your findings, as indeed I think I told you
the last time we talked together, there are, however, some
points about the African status which are very interesting, and
in a measure reflect doubt on the age old endemicity of the disease
in that country.

The above referred to doubts are not sufficiently well
grounded to constitute a valid argument, and I therefore reiterate
my concurrence in your findings and will tell you about the
African matters when I see you, as I think they will interest you
considerably.

I hope you are feeling very much better and will be soon
able to take a long, quiet rest with the book off your mind.
All my family join me in sending love to you and Laura.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, J. H. White JHW:BK
